p.#text: 179 A (Phaedrus)

Since in this list echoes are found of the only two earlier encomiasts who were not
              represented in the former lists ( Pausanias and
              Aristophanes), it will be seen that the speech of Alcibiades contains references, more
              or less frequent, to sentiments and sayings expressed by every one of the previous
              speakers. It is chiefly in his description of himself that Alcibiades echoes the
              language of the first five speakers, and in his description of Socrates that he echoes
              the language of Socrates. The general impression made on the mind of the reader who
              attends to the significance of the facts might be summed up briefly in the form of a
              proportion: as Alcibiades is to Socrates in point of practical excellence and truth,
              so are the first five speeches to the discourse of Socrates-Diotima in point of
              theoretical truth and excellence. But while this is, broadly speaking, true of the  inner nature () of
              Socrates as contrasted with that of Alcibiades, we must bear in mind that in his
              outward appearance () Socrates is
              conformed to this world and, posing as an  of a similar type to Alcibiades himself, serves to illustrate the
              theories and sentiments of the earlier speeches.

Lastly, attention may be drawn to one other parallel in Alcibiades' discourse which
              appears to have passed unnoticed hitherto. It can scarcely be a mere coincidence that
              Alcibiades' progress in eroticsin other words, the temptation of
              saint Socratesis marked by a series of stages (,  ff.) until it reaches its climax in , and that a similar  by gradual stages (210 A ff.,  ff.) up to the final communion with Ideal Beauty had been described as the
              characteristic method of the true  It seems reasonable
              to suppose that the method of  love is designedly
              represented as thus in detail contrasting with, and as it were caricaturing, the
              method of  love: for thereby an added emphasis is laid upon
              the latter.

div1.head: vii. The Dialogue as a Whole: its Scope and Design.

p.#text:
No small degree of attention has been paid by the expositors of our dialogue to the
              question regarding its main purportde universi operis
              consilio. It is plausibly argued that there must be some one leading
              thought, some fundamental idea, which serves to knit together its various parts and to
              furnish it with that unity which should belong to it as an
              artistic whole. But wherein this leading idea consists has been matter of controversy.
              Some, like Stallbaum, are content to adopt the simplest and most obvious view that
              Eros is the central idea, and that the design of the whole is to establish a doctrine
              of Eros. Others, again, have supposed that Plato was mainly concerned to furnish his
              readers with another specimen of the right method of handling philosophical problems.
              But although either of these views, or both combined, might be thought to supply an
              adequate account of the design and scope of the dialogue if it had ended with the
              speech of Socrates, they are evidently inadequate when applied to the dialogue as it
              stands, with the addition of the Alcibiades scenes. In fact, this last part of the
              dialoguethe Third Act, as we have called itmight be construed as
              suggesting an entirely different ,namely,
              laudation of Socrates in general, or perhaps rather (as Wolf argued) a defence of
              Socrates against the more specific charge of unchastity.  That this is
              one purpose of the dialogue is beyond dispute: many indications testify, as has been
              shown, that Plato intended here to offer an  Yet it would be a mistake to argue from this that the main design of
              the dialogue as a whole lies in this apologetic. Rather it is necessary to combine the
              leading idea of this last Act with those of the earlier Acts in such a way as to
              reduce them, as it were, to a common denominator. And when we do this, we
              findas I agree with Rckert in believingthat the
              dominant factor common to all three Acts is nothing else than the personality of
              Socrates,Socrates as the ideal both of philosophy and of love, Socrates as
              at once the type of temperance and the master of magic. Our study of the framework as
              well as of the speeches has shown us how both the figure of Socrates and his theory
              dominate the dialogue, and that to throw these into bolder relief constitutes the main
              value of all the other theories and figures. This point has been rightly emphasized by
              Rckert (p. 252): utique ad Socratem animus advertitur; quasi sol
              in medio positus, quem omnes circummeant, cuius luce omnia collustrantur, vimque
              accipiunt vitalem, Socrates proponitur, et Socrates quidem philosophus, sapiens,
              temperans. Quem iuxta multi plane evanescunt, ceteri vix obscure comparent, ipse
              Agatho, splendidissimum licet sidus ex omnibus, ut coram sole luna
              pallescit.

p:
It seems clear, therefore, that the explanation of the
              Hauptzweck of our dialogue which was given long ago by
              Schleiermacher is the right onepropositum est Platoni in
              Convivio ut philosophum qualem in vita se exhiberet, viva imagine
              depingeret: it is in the portrait of the ideal Socrates that the main
              object of the dialogue is to be sought.

p.#text:
The theory of Teichmller and Wilamowitz as to the occasion on which the
              dialogue was produced has no direct bearing on the question of design. They suppose
              that it was written specially for recital at a banquet in Plato's Academy; and,
              further, that it was intended to provide the friends and pupils of Plato with a model
              of what such a banquet ought to be. But it would be absurd to estimate the design of a
              work of literary art by the temporary purpose which it subserved; nor can we easily
              suppose that Plato's main interest lay in either imagining or recording gastronomic
              successes as such. Equally unproven, though more suggestive, is the idea of Gomperz
              that this dialogue  was inspired by an
              affection for Dion.

div1.head: viii. The Date.
p:
We must begin by drawing a distinction between a the date of the actual Banquet, b
              that of Apollodorus' narrative, and c that of the composition of the dialogue by
              Plato.

p.title: Ol.
p.#text:
a That the date of the Banquet is B.C. 416 ( 90. 4) is asserted by
              Athenaeus (v. ):  (sc. ) . It is true, as
              Sauppe and others have pointed out, that the description in  (, cp.
                
              ), would suit the Great Dionysia better than the Lenaea; but
              this discrepancy need not shake our confidence in the date assigned by Athenaeus. The
              year 416 agrees with the mention of Agathon as 
              (175 B), and of Alcibiades as at the height of his influence (216 B) before the
              ill-fated Sicilian expedition.

title: Ran.
Symp.
note.#text:
Fritzsche's view that Ar.
                   72 implies the previous death ( 405) of A. is refuted by Rettig,  pp. 59 ff.

p.#text:
b The date of the prefatory scene may be approximately fixed from the following
              indications: (1) It was a considerable number of years after the actual Banquet
                ( 172 C,  173 A); (2) several years ( 172 C) after Agathon's departure from Athens; (3) within
              three years of the commencement of Apollodorus' close association with Socrates (172
              C); (4) before the death of Socrates (as shown by the pres. tense  172 C); (5) before the death of Agathon (as
              shown by the perf.  172 C). It seems
              probable that Agathon left Athens about 408, at the latest, and resided till 399 at
              the court of Archelaus of Macedon.
              Hence any date before 399 will satisfy the two last data. And since the two first data
              demand a date as far removed as possible from the years 416 and 408, we can hardly go
              far wrong if we date the dramatic setting circ. 400 B.C.

title: Pol.
Phaedrus
p.#text:
c We come now to the more important question of  The  evidence available is but
              slight. A posterior limit is afforded by two references in Aristotle
              ( II. 4. 1262^{b} 12:  II. 415^{a}
              26), a possible allusion by Aeschines ( 345 B.C.),
              and a probable comic allusion by Alexis in his  ( Athen. XIII. 562 A)a work which probably cannot be
              dated before 370 at the earliest.

p.#text:
The  evidence is more extensive but somewhat
              indefinite. It is commonly assumed that in  ()  we have a definite
              reference to the  of Mantinea in 385 B.C.
              But even if this be grantedas I think it must, in spite of the
              contradiction of Wilamowitzit by no means follows that the dialogue must be
              dated 3854. We find Isocrates ( 126) mentioning the
              same event five years later. All that it affords us is a prior limit. Little weight
              can be given to Dmmler's view that the previous death of Gorgias (circ. 380)
              is implied by the allusion to him in  (). Nor can we lay much stress on the
              conclusions drawn (by Rckert and others) from the absence of reference to
              the re-establishment of Mantinea in 370, or to the exploits of the Theban
              Sacred Band at Leuctra (371), which (as Hug thinks) might
              naturally have been alluded to in .

p.#text:
The evidence of date afforded by stylometric observations is
              not of a convincing character. M. Lutoslawski, it is true, dogmatically asserts that
              the  stands between the  and
                 in the First Platonic Group; but his
              arguments, when examined, prove to be of the most flimsy character. Beyond affording a
              confirmation of the general impression that our dialogue stands somewhere in the
              middle period, the labours of the stylometrists give us little
              assistance. If we choose to date it in 390 they cannot refute us, nor yet if we date
              it 10 or 15 years later. The question as to whether the 
              preceded the  or followed it is one of special interest in view
              of the number of points at which the two writings touch each other. The evidence on
              the whole seems in favour of the priority of the ; but, even if this be
              granted, little light is shed on the date of composition of the ,
              since that of the  eludes precise determination.

note.#text:
Among those who claim priority for
                Xenophon are Bckh, Ast, Delbrck, Rettig, Teichmller,
                Hug, Dmmler, Pfleiderer; on the other side are C. F. Hermann, I. Bruns,
                Schenkl, Gomperz. Beside the broader resemblances set forth by Hug, the foll. refs.
                to echoes may be of interest:  i. 1 =178 A,
                   ii. 23=213 E,  ii. 26 (iv. 24)=185 C,  iv. 14=183
                A, , 
                iv. 15=178 E, ,  iv. 16=178 E iv. 17=181 E,  iv. 19
                (v. 7)=215 A (216 D, ) iv. 23=181 D iv. 25=193
                D iv. 28=217 E iv. 478=188 D iv. 48=188 D iv. 50=189 A, 
                 iv. 53 =219 B v. 1, 7 =218 E (175 E) viii. 1 =218 B (187
                D) viii. 8 =219 D viii. 13=184 B viii. 21=214 C viii. 23=183 A (203 B),  viii. 24=217 E,  viii. 31=179 E viii. 38=209 E viii. 32 (iv. 16)=178 E viii. 34 =182 B viii.
                35 =179 A The last three parallels are specially interesting, since Xen. ascribes to
                Pausan. some of the sentiments which Pl. gives to Phaedrus. Possibly (as Hug,
                Teichm. and others suppose) both writers are indebted to an actual  of the real Pausan., which Pl. is handling more freely, Xen. more
                exactly (cp. I. Bruns, , p. 152).

p.#text:
Equally difficult is it to draw any certain conclusions from the relation in which
              our dialogue stands to the  of Xenophon. That there are many
              points of connexion, many close parallels, between  the two works is
              obvious, but which of the two is prior in date is a problem which has called forth
              prolonged controversy.
              This is not the place to investigate the problem: I can only state my firm opinion
              that the Xenophontic  (whether genuine or not) is the later
              work. But attempts to fix its date are little better than guess-work: Roquette puts it
                 38076; Schanz, after 371; K. Lincke
                ( 1897), after 350.

It will be seen that the available evidence is not sufficient to justify us in
              dogmatizing about the precise date of composition of our dialogue. The most we can say
              is that  3835 seems on the whole the most
              probable period.

The part covered is from  [beginning
              with the word [] after which 40 lines are lost, the next words being  at the end of ] to the end, comprised in 31 columns, of which four (xixxxii) are
              missing entirely, while two others (i and xviii) are represented by small fragments;
              but the remainder is in a very fair state of preservation....The small and well-formed
              but somewhat heavy writing exemplifies a common type of book hand, and probably dates
              from about the year .D....The corrector's ink
              does not differ markedly in colour from that of the text, and in the case of minor
              insertions the two hands are at times difficult to distinguish. But as they are
              certainly not separated by any wide interval of time the question has no great
              practical importance....The text, as so often with papyri, is of an eclectic
              character, showing a decided affinity with no single MS. Compared with the three
              principal witnesses for the  it agrees now with B against TW,
              now with the two latter as against the former, rarely with T against BW or with W against BT. Similarly in a passage cited by Stobaeus
              some agreements with his readings against the consensus of BTW are counterbalanced by
              a number of variations from Stobaeus' text. A few
              coincidences occur with variants peculiar to the inferior MSS., the more noticeable
              being those with Vindob. 21 alone or in combination with Venet. 184 and Parisin. 1642 alone or with Vat.
                229. Of the readings for which there is
              no other authority, including several variations in the order of the words, the
              majority, if unobjectionable, are unconvincing. The more valuable contributions, some
              of which are plainly superior to anything found in other MSS., are: l. 92 [201 D]
                , l. 112 [202 A] the omission of  (so Stallbaum), l. 239 [204 B] , where BTW have a meaningless , l.
              368 [206 C]  as conjectured by Badham  for , l. 471 [208 B]  as restored by Stephanus ( MSS.), l. 517 [209 A] 
              confirming a conjecture of Hug ( MSS.), l. 529
              [209 B]  as conjectured by Stephanus ( MSS.), l. 577 [210 A]  omitted by MSS., l. 699 [212 A] 
                ( BTW), l. 770 [213 B] [ (?) ( MSS), l. 898 [218 D] 
              (probably) with Vind. 21 ( BTW), l. 1142 [222 D]
                 as conjectured by Hirschig ( BTW). On the other hand in many cases the papyrus
              once more proves the antiquity of readings which modern criticism rejects or
              suspects.

p:
It may be added that the editors of the papyrus in citing W have made use of a new
              collation of that MS. by Prof. H. Schne of Basel which often
              supplements and sometimes corrects the report of Burnet. And in this
              edition I have followed the report of W in their apparatus, where available, while
              relying elsewhere upon that given by Burnet.

title: Modern criticism.
Symposium

note.title: E.g.
note.#text:
O. Jahn, Hirschig,
                Badham, Cobet, Naber, Hartmann. On the other hand, sensible protests have been made
                by Teuffel and Vahlen; and Rettig's text is, if anything,
              ultra-conservative.

p.#text:
(2)  Much attention has been paid by Continental
              critics during the last century to the text of the , and for
              the most part they have proceeded on the assumption that the text is largely vitiated
              by interpolations. Even Schanz and Hug, who may be regarded as moderate and
              cautious critics in comparison with such extremists as Jahn and Badham, have gone to
              unnecessary lengths in their use of the obelus. Hug, while admitting that we must take
              into account the freedom and variety of Plato's style and that it is folly to rob a
              writer of his individuality by pruning away any and every expression which is in
              strict logic superfluous, and while admitting also that regard must be paid to the
              characteristic differences of the various speeches in our dialogue, which forbid our
              taking any one speech as the norm with which others should be squared,yet
              maintains that in the speeches, and especially in those of Pausanias and Socrates, he
              can detect a number of unquestionable glosses. No doubt there are some cases in these
              speeches in which it is not unreasonable to suspect interpolation, but even Hug and
              Schanz have, I believe, greatly exaggerated the number of such cases; and I agree with
              the editor of the Oxford text in regarding the certain instances of corruption or
              interpolation as extremely few. Consequently, in the text here printed I have diverged
              but seldom from the ancient tradition, and such changes as I have made have been more
              often in the  direction of verbal alteration than of omission. I have,
              however, recorded in the textual notes a selection of the proposed alterations, futile
              though I consider most of them to be.

(1) Ast, Hommel, Stallbaum and Jowett look for it in the word , which they take to be a play on  (bald-headed, so Jowett) or  (bald-coot) in allusion to the

p.title: Sat.

(4) Rettig, reading , omits (with

              This seems, on the whole, the best and simplest solution. Glaucon, at a distance
              behind, feigns ignorance of the identity of the Phalerian, and
              shouts after Apollodorus Ho there! you Phalerian, halt, in a
              stop thief! tone. It is plausible to suppose also that a certain
              contempt is conveyed in the description 
              (Wapping-ite): porttowns are often places of unsavoury repute:
              cp.

              fugitivis.

title: P. L. G.

p.#text:
The force of  is to indicate that the proverb, when amended, still,
              after all holds good. Two forms of the proverb are extant, viz. (1)
                 (see Schol. , Athen. IV. 27); and
              (2) . The latter form is vouched for by the  quoted by Athen. I. 8 A (Bergk  p. 704), :
              Bacchyl. fr. 33 (22 Blass)  [cp. Zenob. II. 19 ]: Cratinus fr. 111
              (Mein.) 
               
               : also a
              number of post-Platonic passages cited by Hug, such as Plut. 
              VII. 6  According to the Scholiast (1) is the original
              form, which was altered () to (2) by
              Cratinus and Eupolis; and this is the view adopted by Stallbaum, Rettig and others.
              But Hug's elaborate investigation of the matter proves convincingly, I think, that the
              Scholiast is wrong and that the form with  was the original, of which the form with  is a parody by Eupolis (or Cratinus). This view, first
              suggested by Schleiermacher, is also supported by Bergk (
              Bacchyl. fr. 33): Schol. Plat. Sym. 
              a vero aberrat cum dicit a principio  fuisse, quamquam fidem habuerunt cum alii tum Mller
                 II. 481: neque enim par fuit Herculem tam gravi opprobrio
              hospitem laedere. Eupolis primus, ut videtur, ludibundus  substituit. Locum difficilem Platonis, qui falso criminatur Homerum
              corrupisse proverbium quod ille omnino non respexit, nemodum probabiliter expedivit.
              Alia varietas, quam nostri homines commenti sunt, , omni auctoritate destituta est. The main difficulty in
              the way of accepting this view lies in the words . For even if (with most modern editors) we accept
              Lachmann's brilliant conjecture (), the change thus involved is so slight that it could
              hardly be called a , nor could the alteration
              involved in the Homeric account be spoken of as a  double one (). The former objection, if it
              stood alone, might be obviated by the device of inserting  before : but in view of
              the passage as a whole this device is inadmissible. We seem forced to conclude that,
              whatever the original form of the proverb may have been (and as to this Hug's view is
              probably right), the form which Plato had here in mind was the form (1) given by
              Eupolis: and if Plato knew this form to be only a parody of the original (2), we must
              suppose further that the serious way in which he deals with it, as if it really were a
              wise saw, is only a piece of his funa playful display
              of Socratic irony. (Cp. Teuffel,  XXIX. pp.
              1412.)

p.title: Rhein. Mus.
p.#text:
. These words
              are difficult. They should naturally mean (as Stallb. puts it) si quando
              nemo vobis est propositus; and so Stallb. proposes to construe them, taking
              the clause as dependent on and limiting . This, however, is, as Hug argues, almost certainly wrong. If we
              retain the text of the MSS. we can only explain the phrase by assuming an
              ellipseserve up what dishes you like (as you usually do)
              whenever no one is in command. So Zeller renders tragt uns
              getrost auf, was ihr wollt, wie ihr es gewohnt seid, wenn man euch nicht unter
              Aufsicht nimmt, etc.; and Rieckher ( XXXIII. p.
              307) Machet es wie ihr es immer macht, wenn man euch nicht beaufsichtigt
              (und das habe ich ja noch nie gethan), und setzt uns vor was ihr
              mget. Most of the emendations offered (see ) are based on the assumption that the clause in question qualifies
              the leading clause (): none of them
              are convincing, and the construction  (the pres.-perf.) assumed by Schanz and Hug lacks support.
              If compelled to resort to conjecture, the best device might be to read  for ,
              cut out the  after , and change the mood of the verb to following in part the suggestions of Usener. The
              ordinary text does not admit of Jowett's rendering, serve up whatever you
              please, for there is no one to give you orders; hitherto I have never left you to
              yourselves. As regards the force of , L. Schmidt explains the clause to mean nunquam
              autem rem ita ut nunc institui, implying that the concession to the slaves
              was unusual: Teuffel, on the contrary, sees in it a piece of ostentation on the part
              of Agathon, boasting of his humanity. The former is clearly wrong.

              frequent. Moreover, Dionysus was sometimes represented (as by Praxilla of Sicyon, c.
              450 B.C.) to be a son of Aphrodite; and in Aristoph.  490 (Df.)  is termed . For the traditional inter-connexion of

title: Theog.

p.#text:
The reference is to  116
              ff.  Cp. Ar.  693 ff.  The order of the text I have adopted, in the passage
              following, is that proposed by Schanz, except that he reads , while Burnet, accepting the
              transposition, prints  instead of . Hug and others eject the clause  as a marginal prose paraphrase of the words
              of Hesiod; since, as it stands in the traditional order, the clause is obviously
              tautologous: but tautology is in itself no objection, but rather characteristic of
              Ph.'s style  (see Teuffel in  XXIX. p. 133); and
              there is force in Hermann's remark aegre intelligo quomodo aliquis
              clarissimis poetae verbis (paraphrasin) addendam existimaverit, multoque verisimilius
              videtur Hesiodi locum...postmodo adscriptum...irrepsisse. I bracket the
              clause as a gloss on . The clause  is rightly defended by Hug, against
              Voegelin and others, on the grounds that (1)  in the following sentence is more appropriate after three than
              after two instances, and (2) Agathon in , when
              alluding to Phaedrus's speech, expressly mentions . The authority of Hesiod is similarly cited by Plut.  756 E.

              logographer at all (see Jevons,  p. 299).

              fact that A. is put last as due to his being an , the others .

              The principal military offences at Athens were dealt with by one law. A
              citizen was liable to indictment, and, if convicted, to disfranchisement for (1)

              Cowardice in battle: (3) Desertion
              of his post: (4) Desertion from
              the army. Of these terms,
                 was that used in the widest sense, and
              might include any of the others (Smith,  I. 212^{b}).

On Beauty
p.#text:
Youth
              is like the flower of the field, so soon passeth it away, and it is
              gone. Cp. Mimn. 2. 7 : Theogn. 1305   :
              Sgur's refrain Ah! le Temps fait passer l'Amour:
              Spenser () For that same goodly hew of white
              and red, With which the cheeks are sprinckled, shal decay, And those sweete rosy
              leaves, so fairely spred Upon the lips, shall fade and fall away etc.:
                
              : Xen.  VIII. 14 :
              Tyrt. 10. 28 : Mimnerm. 1. 4. So Emerson () The
              radiance of the human form...is only a burst of beauty for a few years or a few
              months, at the perfection of youth, and in most rapidly declines. But we remain lovers
              of it, only transferring our interest to interior excellence.

. Asclepius in
              Homer is not more than : in Pindar
                ( III.) and later poets he is the son of Apollo and Coronis. The
              earliest seats of his worship seem to have been Thessaly and Boeotia, and his cult, as
              a chthonic and mantic deity, may have its
              roots in a primitive ophiolatry (see Rohde,  I. 141 ff.). Cp.
                 272  Also  67, addressed to A. as  The
              Asclepiadae were a recognized medical guild, with hereditary traditions; their most
              famous schools were at Cos and Cnidus, for which see the account in Gomperz  (E. tr.) vol. I. pp. 275 ff.: cp.  (with Thompson's note).

. The curative value of physical
              training is said to have been emphasized especially by Iccos of Tarentum and Herodicus
              of Selymbria, both 5th century experts in dieting. For the latter as an advocate of
              walking exercise see  (with Schol. ); cp. 
               406 A: for the former, as an example of abstinence, see . That Plato himself recognizes
              the connexion between  and  is shown by such passages as  ff., 464 B ff., , .

. The appositeness of  is not so evident as that of , but the use of the word here is defended by  () and by other exx. of a similar collocation, such as ,  (cp. also  f.). The art which deals with  is regarded as analogous to that which deals with
                , involving a similar command of the
              permutations and combinations, the attractions and repulsions (), of the fundamental qualities.

p.#text:
The words of Heraclitus ( 45)
              are given in  IX. 9 thus: : cp. Plut.  45
                : . Probably, as Burnet holds, the original word used by H. was , not , and  combines the
              original sense of structure with the musical sense
              octave, the point of the simile being (see Campbell,
                 p. 244) as the arrow leaves the string the hands
              are pulling opposite ways to each other, and to the different parts of the bow (cf.
              Plato,  4. 439); and the sweet note of the lyre is due to a similar
              tension and retention. The secret of the universe is the same. That is to
              say, the world, both as a whole and in its parts, is maintained by the equilibrium
              resultant from opposite tensions. For more detailed discussion of the theory see
              Burnet,  pp. 158 ff., Zeller,  (E. T.) vol. II. pp. 33 ff. The  H. had in mind is probably, as Bernays suggested, the Scythian
              bow the  of Arist.
                 III. 1412^{b} 35 (see the woodcut in Smith,  arcus).

There are two difficulties in this passage: (1)
              the singular verb after the plural subjects is harsh; to explain it we must assume a
              mental unification of the subjects, of which similar but easier instances occur in
                , 618 D, . We might evade this difficulty
              by removing the colon at , marking  as parenthetic, and thus construing
                 as the direct subject of . (2) We should naturally expect  to have the same reference  here as
                 has above ( to the combinations of elements in which the bad Eros predominates),
              whereas it seemingly stands in agreement with : this being so, what does  precisely mean? For it cannot well retain, in this connexion,
              its proper meaning as genitive of 
              the laws of affinity (186 C, ). Ought we, then, to put a stop after  and begin a new sentence with ?

              that opinion on the matter was not uniform: see also Plutarch,  II. 368 C, 371 F ff.

p.#text:
The clause  is condemned
              by most edd. It is an objection to the phrase that, as Rettig notes, we ought
              naturally to supply with it not only the appropriate  but also the inappropriate : this objection however is not insuperable, and if necessary
                 might be transposed. It is argued on the
              other hand by Hommel and Vgelin that a second simile is really required, the
              sorb-slicing describing only the mode of operation, whereas the egg-slicing adds the
              idea of ease and facility. That 
              was a proverbial saying is shown by Plut.  24, p. 770 B
                . Rckert supposes
              ovorum per crines dissectionem ludi genus fuisse; fortasse ex ovorum
              dissectione per crines facta convivae futura praedicere solebant: Zeller
              writes vielleicht ein Gesellschafts- oder Liebesspiel, das darin bestanden
              haben knnte, dass zwei Tischgenossen sich in die zwei Hlften eines
              hartgesottenen Eies theilten, nachdem es mit einem dem Einen von ihnen ausgezogenen
              Haare zerschnitten war, also ein griechisches Vielliebchen. It is, perhaps,
              possible that it had some connexion with (Orphic) magic and divination by . For the process of bisection, cp. .

. Here  denotes, of course, the result rather than the

                ( VIII. 479). Iapetus was father of Prometheus, and grandfather of
              Deucalion, the Greek Adam: hence older than
              Iapetus might be rendered ante-preadamite.

. Both the punctuation
              and reading of this verse are doubtful. Rckert, Stallb., and the Zurich edd.
              print commas after  and , Hug and Burnet only after , Hommel after  and
                . It would appear, however, from the Homeric
              passage ( V. 391 = XII. 168,   ), of which this is obviously an echo, that no stop should be
              placed after , but rather after  or : while
              the compound word , applied to a sect
                () in Corinth who claimed to be able  (see Hesych. and Suid. ; also Welcker  3. 63; Rohde
                 II. p. 88; and 
              ), makes it probable that  are meant to go closely together. Further, although as Zeller
              argues it is appropriate enough in general to describe Love as is qui non
              aequoris solum sed etiam humani pectoris turbas sedat (cp.
               XXIV. 128 ff., Catull. 68. 18), still the reversion to
              human  after mentioning waves and winds is a
              little curious, and it is tempting to adopt Hommel's conjecture  which, if  can bear
              the sense of sea-depths (see L. and S. 
              ) would furnish a more satisfactory
              disposition of ideaspeace on land and on sea, repose in heaven
              above and in the depths below. Or, if we assumed that an original  (=)
              was corrupted by haplography to , a fair sense
              would be obtained. If the ordinary text be kept, we may notice (with Vgelin)
              how the force of the prepos. in  varies in the style of the Sophists. In  we have a similar
              combination, , the only
              other Platonic ex. of  being .  as an adj. occurs in .

These words have given rise to much discussion
              and many emendations (see ). Two main lines of
              interpretation are possible: either (1) we may suppose that maritime allusions are to
              be sought in these words to match those in ; or (2) we may suppose the latter set of words to be used in a merely
              metaphorical sense. Badham adopts line (1); so too Schtz regards the whole
              figure as borrowed e re nautica. Nautis enim saepe  naufragii,  terrae,  in difficultate navigandi, 
              nauseantibus...accidere solet; and he takes the following four substt.
                () as referring in order to these four
              conditions. And, adopting this line, I myself formerly proposed to read (for ) . The 2nd line of explanation is adopted a by those who attempt to
              defend the vulgate, and b by some who have recourse to emendation. Thus a Stallb.
              commends Ast's view that  can stand here because
              Agathon's speech is full of merus verborum lusus; while Hommel
              takes the words  etc. as e re
              amatoria depromta, expressing the affections of the lover while seeking the
              society of his beloved, and connects (in the reverse order)  with  with  with ,
              and  with . On the other hand, b Rettigwhile altering the second
              pair to also
              disregards the maritime metaphor and  understands the passage
              berhaupt von Kriegsgefahren und dem in solchen geleisteten
              Beistand, comparing the allusions to such matters by Phaedrus (179 A) and
              Alcibiades (220 D ff.). Here Rettig is, I believe, partly on the right track; since
              the clue to the sense (and reading) here is to be looked for in Alcibiades' eulogy of
              Socrates. We find  echoed there (219 E ), and  also (220 E , 
              ) and  may be defended by the allusions to Socrates'  (215 C ff.,  ff.). Thus the
              only doubtful phrase is , which has no
              parallel in Alcib.'s speech, and is also objectionable here because of the proximity
              of . In place of it I propose  (cp.  48 A), of which we
              find an echo (in sense if not in sound) in 
              . For maritime terms in connexion with , cp.  194 C :
               137 A :  264 A;  29 B. So
              both  and 
              in Dionys. Chalc. 4. 1 ff.   :  5. 1 ff.
                ,    . Cp. also Cic.
               IV. 5. 9 quaerebam utrum panderem vela orationis statim, an
              eam...dialecticorum remis propellerem. For , of Eros, cp.  in later Stoic literature (Rohde  II. 316):
              Epict.  I. 14. 12; Menander (

                  (=, cp. ). For 
              used metonymously, cp.  ( on ); so Emerson, Beauty

              Eros. Cp. also Procl.  p. 40.

p.#text:
These words have been variously interpreted: (1)
              Lehrs and Prantl construe the genitives as subjective (love felt  a mother); (2) Ast as objective (love
                 a mother): (3) Rckert, followed by
              Hommel and Hug, takes them to be genn. of origin; so too Zeller renders ich
              meine damit aber nicht, ob er eine Mutter oder einen Vater hat. Of these,
              (1) seems the least probable in point of sense, and with subjective genitives  would be superfluous. It is a serious objection (as Hug
              admits) to (3) that it compels us to regard the absurdity
                () of the question as lying in its form
              rather than its substance. That the absurdity lies in the
              substance of the statement is shown, e.g., by 
               (cp. ). But if so, recourse
              must be had to textual alteration: we must strike out either the second , with Sommer, or the whole block of words , as Hug (followed by Jowett) suggests.
              This, however, is a hazardous alternative. On the whole, then, the explanation (2) put
              forward by Ast seems the most probable. Construing, I do not ask whether
              Eros has for its object a father or a mother, since to ask whether Eros is  for a parent  were an absurd
              question, the point will be taken to lie in the fact that , as properly denoting 
              passion, cannot naturally have for its object a parent. The same interpretation might
              be kept if we struck outas perhaps we oughtthe words , and construed the question
              would be absurd if ( granting that) Eros is (really)  (i.e. sex-love).

. Rettig
              approves Stallbaum's explanation, 
               ut mox loquitur.
              Vult autem cogitari de patris notione, qualem mente informatum habemus. But
              the use of the neuter in apposition to the masc. is sufficient to indicate that
              cogitari de patris notione; and it is most natural to regard
                 as implying a reference to the
              previous use of this very word, .

                ( IV. 39) identifies the garden of
              Zeus with Paradise, Poros with Adam, Penia with the Serpent. With the
              intoxication and its results we might compare the O. T. stories of Noah and his sons
              and of Lot and his daughters. For the neo-Platonic interpretation of the myth, see
              Plotinus  III. 5. 2, 292 F ff., 298 F: cp. also
                IV. C 2. A similar Orphic legend is mentioned by
              Porphyry  16 ( p. 180)
                . Another classical example is the trick played by Lady
              Macbeth on Duncan's spongy officers (his two
              chamberlains Will I with wine and wassail so convince etc.).

p.#text:
Opinions are divided as to the construction of
                : it may be construed (1) as
              nominative and subject, the generic concept (sc. ) is; so Hommel, Vermehren, Hug, Prantl,
              comparing 
               (sc. ) : or
              (2) as adverbial accus. (of respect), in its generic aspect, cp.
                
              : . The latter is certainly
              the more natural mode of construing here, since no genitive () is added. But other difficulties remain: what is the subject of
                , if  is adverbial? Should we a construe with Ficinus (followed by
              Stallb.^{2}, Lehrs, Zeller, Jowett and others) nam summatim quidem omnis
              bonorum felicitatisque appetitio maximus et insidiator amor est cuique? Or
              b should we rather, with Stallb.^{1} and Prantl, supply  as the subject of  and
              construe  as the predicate? To
              my mind the latter is the more natural method. Next arises the question, how are we to
              deal with the last part of the sentence, ? If with most edd. (except Rckert, Stallb.^{2}
              and Rettig) we regard  as corrupt, the best
              plan is to excise the whole clause with Hug (and Stallb.^{1}), since none of the
              corrections of  hitherto proposed (see ) are at all convincing. The chief objection to  is, not so much the meaning of the word itself
              (which may be defended by ), as rather (to quote
              Stallb.^{2}) conjunctio superlativi  cum  positivo.
              But even this objection  is not, I think, insuperable; for if we construe
                 closely with  as all-ensnaring, we get a superlative idea
              which balances , while in sense it is
              supported by , D and Sappho's . If, adopting this explanation, we
              retain the traditional text, it seems best to regard the clause  as an appositional quotation and to construe, with
              Prantl, nmlich jene grsste und fr jeden
              verfngliche Liebe. Hommel is singular in taking  (sc. ), as well as , as
              subject (und das Streben nach dem hchsten Gute, d. i. nach
              Glckseligkeit, ist die grsste Liebe).

p.title: Enn.
p.#text:
. There is much to be
              said for Rettig's view that this sentence (as well as the next) is a gloss. As he
              argues, the words gehren also ihrem Inhalte nach nicht an die
              Stelle, an welcher sie stehen, sondern sie mssten nach dem Satze  folgen. An dieser Stelle collidiren
              sie aber mit den gleichbedeutenden Worten ,  fr deren Glosse ich sie
              ansehe. Worauf sollten auch die Worte  gehen, wenn ihnen die Worte  unmittelbar vorangingen? It is just possible,
              however, to retain the clause as a kind of parenthetic addendum to the preceding
              sentence, which forestalls, somewhat confusingly, the sentences . The omission of the article before , confirmed by the Papyrus, is certainly an

              (as Wolf and Hommel suggest) to the fact that the sophistic, as contrasted with the
              Socratic, method was that of didactic monologue (
              )the lecture

              developes her own doctrine without the aid of further question-and-answer. Stallb.,
              however, explains the phrase as intended to ridicule the pretended omniscience of the
              sophists; Rettig sees in it an indication that what follows is meant, in part, as a
              parody of the earlier speeches; and by Ast and Schleierm. it is taken to refer only to
              the dogmatic tone of . For , cp.  (applied to Hades);  applied to Eros, ;

p.#text:
. Here Diotima
              passes on to the final section of her discourse on erotics (see 
              ). Hug and P. Crain (following C. F. Hermann and Schwegler)
              suppose that  indicates that what follows
              is something beyond the ken of the  Socrates, whose
              view  they regard as correctly represented in Xen. 
              VIII. 97 ff. But although we may admit (with Thompson,  p. 158)
              that we often find Plato making his ideal Socrates criticise the views the
              real Socrates held, we are not hereby justified in assuming such criticism
              on every possible occasion. And, in the case before us, another and more probable
              explanation of the words lies to hand. Socrates throughoutwith his usual
              ironydepicts himself as a mere tiro in the hands of the Mantinean mistress;
              but he is still, in spite of his mock-modesty, the ideal philosopher of Alcibiades'
              encomium. As it was a part of his irony that he had already (201 E) put himself on the
              level of Agathon and the rest of the unphilosophic, so the contemptuous  here serves to keep up the same ironical
              fiction,i.e. it applies neither to the ideal nor to the real (historical)
              Socrates, but to the hypothetical Socratesthe disguise assumed by the ideal
              Socrates when he played the part of pupil (cp. Rettig's ,
              and F. Horn  p. 248). The attitude of Socr. may be
              illustrated by the words of S. Paul (1  iv. 6)  For , see next

              is most natural to refer it, and  following,
              to the  and  of , and to render by
              discourse, argument (with Gomperz, Stewart
              and Zeller). This rendering has in its favour the fact that this is the usual sense of
                 ()
              throughout this dialogue. (2) Or  may mean
              concept; so Rettig, who comments: Die Ideen sind
              nicht blosse Begriffe, sie sind vielmehr Existenzen, , wie Aristoteles sich ausdrckt, und Bedingungen des
              Seins und Werdens der Dinge der Sinnenwelt. Cp. , , , in which places (to quote Thompson)
                 is equivalent to  or , of which
                 is the objective counterpart.
              This more technical sense is, perhaps, less probable in the present context; but,
              after all, the difference between the two renderings is not of vital importance. The
              essence of the statement, in either case, is that the Idea is not dependent upon
              either corporeal or mental realization, i.e. that it is not subjective, as a quality
              or product of body or mind, but an objective, self-conditioned entity. A third
              possible sense of  is
              ratio, or mathematical relation. Perhaps
              formula would best render the word here.

p.#text:
These were statuettes representing a Silenus
              playing a flute or pipe; the interiors were hollow and served as caskets to hold
              little figures of gods wrought in gold or other precious materials. But the precise
              fashion of their construction and how they opened () is by no means clear. (1) Hug thinks they were made with a
              double door (): similarly Stallb. and Hommel
              (in contrariis Silenorum lateribus duobus duo foramina erant, quae
              epistomio quodam claudi poterant). (2) Schulthess supposes that one section
              telescoped into the other (Schiebt man sie auseinander, so erblickt man
              inwendig Gtterbilder). (3) Panofka, with Schleiermacher, supposes
              that the top came off like a lid. (4) Lastly, Rettig denkt an ein
              Auseinandernehmen in zwei Hlfte, though exactly how this differs
              from (3) he does not clearly explain. Butas Rettig himself
              observesmag es verschiedene Arten solche Gehuse
              gegeben haben, and in the absence of further evidence it would be rash to
              decide which of the possible patterns is here intended: the language () rather favours the idea that the
              figures split into two, either horizontally or verticallypossibly, also,
              with a hinge. Cp. Synes.  153, p. 
              : Maximus  c. ix. t. II. p. 201 f. (ed. Cord.) 
              
               (cp. Etym. Magn. 
              ): Xen.  IV. 19; Julian
                 VI. p. .

. Most of the later
              critics (including Voeg., Teuffel, Hug) agree in ejecting this clause. Rettig, who
              defends it, writes: die Worte gehen auf den vermeintlichen Stumpfsinn des
              S., wie er so hufig mit roher Sinnlichkeit verbunden ist...Die Worte
                 den obigen  gegenstzlich
              gegenberstanden...Da nicht blos die 
              , so wrde ohne
              unsere Worte die folgende Frage  kaum motivirt sein. But (as generally interpreted)
              the clause seems hardly pertinent to the main argument, which is the contrast between
              the outward appearance of eroticism and the inner  of Socr.: the clause  does nothing to strengthen the case for the reference to  here; while there is no reason to suppose that
              professions of ignorance were specially characteristic of Sileni (in spite of the
              story of Midas and Silenus in Plut.  115 C
                (.) ). If retained as it stands the clause is
              best taken closely with the previous words, as expressing an erotic symptom.
              [Possibly, however, for  we should read  and for , taking the words as masc. (sc. ).] This implies of course that  bears the sense agnoscit (and  the opposite), for which cp. Eur.  1105 ff. :  767   . (Cp. for this sense, Vahlen  II. 63 f.)

title: D. A.
Hist. Gk. Lit.
p.#text:
A playful allusion to the  employed by Alcib. in his encomium (see ). For satyric drama see
              Smith,  II. 860 b: The satyr-drama was so-called
              because the Chorus consisted of satyrs attendant on Dionysus...it was aptly described
              as : Jevons,
                 p. 186.
An echo of the language of Alcib. in .

. Dictum hoc
              eleganter cum amphibolia quadam, ut et de spatio possit cogitari et de animorum
              disiunctione (Stallb.): cp. .

. The original order of the
              places on this ()  was (1) Agathon, Socrates (see D): then Alcibiades on his entrance had seated himself in the
              middle (213 B ), thus making the order (2) Agathon,
              Alcib., Socr.: now Socrates invites Agathon to shift his position so as to change the
              order to (3) Alcib., Socr., Agathon: presently, in the sentence following, Alcibiades
              suggests that, instead of this, Agathon should take the middle place (), which would result in the order (4)
              Alcib., Agathon, Socrates. But the adoption of this last order is, as Socr. hastens to
              point out, impossible, inasmuch as it would cause serious dislocation in the series of
                 which are bound to proceed in order from left
              to right (see ), each speaker taking for his
              theme his next neighbour on the right. If the order (4) were adopted, it would be the
              duty of the next speaker, Agathon, to eulogize Socrates, a task already performed by
              Alcib. himself; whereas by adopting the order (3), the next speech would fall to
              Socr., and he would have for his theme Agathon, an arrangement unobjectionable in
              itself and well-pleasing to Socr. (, ) as well as to
              Agathon (, ).

This is artistic selection disguised under the

. The gist
              of it was...: cp.

Cp. 
              . Here both  and  are emphatic,
              with no distinction between them implied. The point of Socrates' argument is that the
                 poet must be master of the art of poetry in its universal,
              generic aspect, and therefore of both its included species, tragedy and comedy. This
              thought, if developed, might be shown to mean that full knowledge both of  and of , and of
              the effects of the one on the other, is requisite to form a master-poet. Which is
              equivalent to saying that, just as the ideal State requires the philosopherking, so
              ideal Art is impossible without the . The thesis here maintained by Socrates finds in the
              supreme instance of Shakspere both illustration and confirmation: The Merry
              Wives came from the same hand as Othello and
              Lear.
